p: Global warming and ocean acidification are already affecting the physiology, behaviour, phenology, demography, abundance, and distribution of many marine species [ 14]. Elevated temperature ( T) affects fish performance and growth through increasing metabolic rates and respiratory demands, leading to a reduced aerobic scope for important life-supporting activities such as feeding, somatic growth, maturation, and predator avoidance [ 15â€“ 17]. Ocean acidification raises the energetic costs involved with calcification and acid-base regulation [ 18, 19] and can impair neural functioning [ 20]. Besides such direct effects, there is a suite of indirect effects that can impact species persistence and diversity under global change [ 21].
